title: Outdoorsy Things to Do in Chhattisgarh, India
text:
Photo by Vishal mallik on Unsplash


Chhattisgarh, located in the central-eastern part of India, is often touted as the “Rice Bowl of India.” But beyond its agricultural significance, the state is a treasure trove of natural beauty, ancient history, and cultural splendor. If you’re an outdoor enthusiast, Chhattisgarh has an array of activities that can quench your thirst for adventure and scenic beauty. Let’s dive into some of the most exhilarating outdoorsy things you can indulge in when visiting this fascinating state.

Chitrakote Waterfalls : Often referred to as the ‘Niagara Falls of India’, the Chitrakote Waterfalls are the broadest waterfalls in the country. Located on the Indravati River, it’s a sight to behold, especially during the monsoon season when the waters are in full spate.
Kanger Valley National Park : A paradise for nature lovers, this national park houses the famous Kutumsar caves and Kailash caves. You can explore these subterranean wonders, witness unique stalactite and stalagmite formations, and even spot diverse wildlife species in the park.
Tirathgarh Waterfalls : Cascading from a height of about 300 feet, the Tirathgarh Waterfalls is another scenic marvel of Chhattisgarh. The falls split into multiple cascades, creating a surreal and picturesque environment.
Indravati National Park : Home to the endangered wild buffalo, this national park offers a rich bio-diversity. Safaris are organized for tourists to witness the diverse fauna including tigers, leopards, and numerous bird species.
Trekking at Mainpat : Known as the ‘Shimla of Chhattisgarh’, Mainpat is a plateau covered with lush greenery. It offers several trekking trails that wind through dense forests, waterfalls, and offer breathtaking views of the valleys.
Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary : Spread over an area of around 245 sq km, this sanctuary is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts. You can spot animals like leopards, porcupines, pythons, and various species of deer.
Sirpur Archaeological Site : While it’s primarily a historical site, the open-air ruins and lush green surroundings make it an exciting outdoor experience. Explore ancient temples, monasteries, and structures dating back to the 5th-8th centuries AD.
Rafting on River Indravati : For those seeking adrenaline, white-water rafting in the turbulent waters of River Indravati offers a thrilling experience. The river’s rapids provide a challenging adventure for enthusiasts.
Camping : There are numerous spots in Chhattisgarh that offer camping opportunities. From the forests of Barnawapara to the plains of Mainpat, you can camp under the stars and experience the serenity of nature.
Biking : The topographical diversity of Chhattisgarh offers ample opportunities for mountain biking. Trails through dense forests, meandering rivers, and rocky terrains challenge both novice and seasoned bikers.
Visit Ghatarani Waterfalls : Located near Raipur, Ghatarani is a popular picnic spot. The dense forests surrounding the falls, the serene ambiance, and the temple dedicated to Goddess Durga nearby, make it a must-visit.

Conclusion
Chhattisgarh, with its rich tapestry of forests, waterfalls, wildlife, and ancient ruins, offers an array of outdoor activities that cater to every kind of traveler. Whether you’re a history buff, nature lover, or an adventure junkie, this state promises unforgettable experiences amidst its pristine landscapes. So, pack your bags and get ready to dive into the untouched beauty of Chhattisgarh.

title: Outdoorsy Things to Do in Karnataka, India
text:
Photo by Nandan Upadhya on Unsplash


Karnataka, located in the southwestern region of India, is a treasure trove of natural beauty, historical landmarks, and vibrant culture. From its pristine beaches to its lush Western Ghats, the state offers a plethora of outdoor activities for nature lovers, adventure enthusiasts, and history buffs. Here’s a detailed guide to some of the best outdoorsy things to do in Karnataka:

Trekking in the Western Ghats:

Kudremukh Trek: Located in the Chikkamagaluru district, Kudremukh is a popular trekking destination known for its picturesque landscapes and rich biodiversity.
Kumara Parvatha Trek: This is one of the most challenging treks in Karnataka, offering stunning views of the Pushpagiri Wildlife Sanctuary.
Tadiandamol Peak: The highest peak in Coorg, Tadiandamol offers a moderate trek with panoramic views of the surrounding hills and valleys.

Beach Hopping:

Gokarna: Famous for its serene beaches like Om Beach and Kudle Beach, Gokarna is a haven for beach lovers and backpackers.
Karwar: Located near the Goa-Karnataka border, Karwar boasts of pristine beaches and a tranquil ambiance.

Waterfall Visits:

Jog Falls: One of the highest plunge waterfalls in India, Jog Falls is a majestic sight, especially during the monsoon season.
Abbey Falls: Located in Coorg, this waterfall is surrounded by coffee plantations and spice estates.

Wildlife Safaris:

Bandipur National Park: Home to tigers, elephants, and various species of deer, Bandipur offers jeep safaris for wildlife enthusiasts.
Nagarhole National Park: Another gem in Karnataka, Nagarhole is known for its rich flora and fauna, including the majestic Bengal tiger.

River Rafting in Dandeli:

Dandeli, located in the Uttara Kannada district, is a hotspot for white-water rafting. The Kali River offers thrilling rapids for both beginners and experienced rafters.

Explore the Ruins of Hampi:

A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Hampi is an ancient village known for its ruins that date back to the Vijayanagara Empire. While it’s a historical site, the boulder-strewn landscapes offer a unique outdoor experience.

Camping in Sakleshpur:

Nestled in the Western Ghats, Sakleshpur is a perfect destination for camping amidst coffee plantations and misty hills.

Caving in Badami:

Badami is renowned for its rock-cut cave temples. However, the region also offers adventurous caving experiences amidst its red sandstone cliffs.

Paragliding in Nandi Hills:

Located near Bangalore, Nandi Hills is a popular spot for paragliding, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding landscapes.

Cycling in Coorg:

The winding roads of Coorg, surrounded by lush greenery and coffee estates, make it an ideal destination for cycling enthusiasts.


Conclusion: Karnataka is a diverse state that offers a mix of natural beauty, adventure, and history. Whether you’re looking to relax on a beach, trek through dense forests, or explore ancient ruins, Karnataka has something for every outdoor enthusiast. So, pack your bags and set out to explore the myriad wonders of this beautiful state!

title: Outdoorsy Things to Do in Arunachal Pradesh, India
text:
Photo by Mayur More on Unsplash


Arunachal Pradesh, situated in the northeastern corner of India, is a mesmerizing state adorned with lush landscapes, snow-capped mountains, and intricate cultural tapestry. Dubbed the “Land of the Rising Sun,” this region offers an array of outdoor activities for both the adventurous spirit and the nature lover. Here’s a curated list of outdoorsy things to do in Arunachal Pradesh.

Tawang Monastery Visit: Tawang Monastery, founded in the 17th century, is the largest monastery in India and second largest in the world. Perched at an elevation of about 3,000 meters, it offers panoramic views of the valley below. The monastery complex houses a library, a museum, and a massive gilded statue of Lord Buddha.
Sela Pass Drive (cover image of this post): Sela Pass, at 13,700 feet, is one of India’s high-altitude mountain passes. Driving through this scenic route covered in snow for most of the year is an unparalleled experience. The nearby Sela Lake, a serene and pristine water body, is another must-visit spot.
River Rafting in Siang: For the adrenaline junkies, the Siang River offers exciting opportunities for white-water rafting. The river’s challenging rapids amidst the scenic landscapes make for a thrilling experience.
Trekking in the Himalayas: Arunachal Pradesh offers a myriad of trekking trails ranging from easy to challenging. Popular treks include the Mechuka Valley Trek, Bailey Trail Trek, and Gorichen Peak Trek. These trails pass through verdant forests, alpine meadows, and offer views of majestic Himalayan peaks.
Pakhui Wildlife Sanctuary Exploration: This sanctuary is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts. Home to tigers, elephants, hornbills, and a variety of other species, it offers the opportunity for jungle safaris and bird watching.
Visit Ziro Valley: Recognized as a World Heritage Site, Ziro Valley is a visual treat with its green paddy fields and traditional Apatani villages. The Ziro Music Festival, held annually, attracts music lovers from across the globe.
Bumla Pass: Close to the Indo-China border, Bumla Pass is a place of significant historical importance. At an elevation of 15,200 feet, the journey to Bumla offers some of the most spectacular views of the Eastern Himalayas.
Explore the Parshuram Kund: Located on the Brahmaputra plateau, Parshuram Kund is a significant Hindu pilgrimage site. Every year during Makar Sankranti, thousands of pilgrims visit the kund to take a holy dip, believed to wash away their sins.
Jaswant Garh War Memorial: Located 21 km from Tawang, this war memorial is dedicated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives during the 1962 Indo-China war. The place provides a deep sense of patriotism amidst the natural beauty of the region.
Visit Namdapha National Park: Namdapha, the third-largest national park in India, is a biodiversity hotspot. From the snow leopard and red panda to myriad bird species, this park is a testament to Arunachal’s rich natural heritage.
Angling in Pasighat: The Siang River near Pasighat is perfect for angling and fishing activities. Golden Mahseer is the prize catch here.
Explore Tribal Villages: Arunachal Pradesh is home to 26 major tribes and over 100 sub-tribes. Visiting tribal villages, witnessing their unique customs, dances, and way of life can be a transformative experience.

Conclusion:
Arunachal Pradesh, with its untouched beauty and diverse topography, is a paradise for outdoor enthusiasts. Whether it’s the thrill of white-water rafting, the tranquility of a Himalayan trek, or the allure of deep-rooted tribal cultures, Arunachal promises an unforgettable experience.

title: Outdoorsy Things to Do in Goa, India
text:
Photo by Miguel Baixauli on Unsplash


Goa, a small state on the southwestern coast of India, is widely known for its beautiful beaches, vibrant nightlife, and rich culture. While many travelers are drawn to its beach parties and laid-back vibe, the region also offers a plethora of outdoor activities for those seeking adventure and a closer communion with nature. Here’s a detailed list of outdoorsy things to do in this tropical paradise:

Beach Hopping : Goa has a vast coastline with over 50 beaches, each having its unique charm. Start with the bustling Baga and Calangute beaches, and gradually explore the quieter ones like Kakolem and Galgibaga.
Water Sports : Indulge in activities like jet-skiing, parasailing, banana boat rides, and windsurfing. Palolem and Anjuna beaches are hotspots for such activities.
Scuba Diving and Snorkeling : The waters surrounding Goa are brimming with marine life. Grande Island and Pigeon Island are perfect spots to explore the underwater world.
Trek to Dudhsagar Waterfalls : Located on the Goa-Karnataka border, this four-tiered waterfall is one of the tallest in India. Trekkers can revel in the surrounding greenery and also enjoy a dip in the water.
Spice Plantation Tours : Witness the cultivation of spices like cardamom, vanilla, and nutmeg. The Sahakari Spice Farm and the Tropical Spice Plantation offer guided tours where you can learn about traditional Goan farming.
Wildlife Sanctuaries : Visit the Bhagwan Mahavir Wildlife Sanctuary or the Mollem National Park. These protected areas are home to diverse fauna like leopards, gaurs, and the Malabar giant squirrel.
Bird Watching : The Dr. Salim Ali Bird Sanctuary, located on the island of Chorão, is a haven for ornithologists and bird lovers. The mangrove habitat is home to species like kingfishers, eagles, and herons.
White Water Rafting : For adrenaline junkies, the Mhadei River offers thrilling white water rafting experiences, especially during the monsoon season.
Kayaking : Navigate the serene backwaters of Goa on a kayak, a perfect activity for early mornings or late afternoons.
Hot Air Balloon Ride : Float over the Goan landscape and catch a bird’s eye view of its picturesque beaches, forests, and towns.
Cycling Tours : Rent a cycle and traverse through Goa’s charming villages, past paddy fields, and along the coastline. This is an eco-friendly way to explore the region’s nooks and corners.
Rock Climbing : The rugged terrains of Goa provide ample opportunities for rock climbing. Sada in Chorla Ghat is a popular spot.
Beach Camping : Away from the bustling resorts, indulge in beach camping, especially in South Goa. Palolem and Galgibaga beaches are known for such camping experiences.
Fishing Trips : Engage with the locals and learn traditional fishing techniques. Many operators offer deep-sea fishing expeditions too.
Windsurfing : With the Arabian Sea on one side and consistent winds, Goa offers optimal conditions for windsurfing. Beginners can head to the Dona Paula bay for lessons.
Paragliding : Feel the rush as you glide over Goa’s coastal belt, enjoying panoramic views of its beaches and sea.

To truly experience Goa’s outdoorsy side, one must step beyond the beach shacks and immerse in its diverse terrains and activities. Whether you’re an adventure seeker or a nature lover, Goa has something to offer for everyone. Remember to respect the environment and local customs as you explore this beautiful land. Safe travels!

title: Outdoorsy Things to Do in Bihar, India
text:
Photo by Arto Suraj on Unsplash


Bihar, located in the eastern part of India, is a state filled with a rich cultural heritage and historical significance. While it might be renowned for its ancient temples, historic sites, and unique traditions, Bihar also offers a variety of outdoor activities for those looking to experience its natural beauty and get adventurous. Here’s a detailed guide to the outdoorsy things you can do in Bihar:

Explore the Nalanda University Ruins: The ancient Nalanda University, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, was once a global center for learning. Though the ruins are more historical than outdoorsy, the vast expanse of the complex offers plenty of walking and exploration opportunities.
Visit the Valmiki National Park: Situated in the West Champaran district, Valmiki National Park is Bihar’s only national park and tiger reserve. Besides the Bengal tiger, the park is home to various other wildlife species like leopards, Indian bison, and several species of deer. Here, you can indulge in a jungle safari, bird watching, or simply trek through the natural landscapes.
Boating in Kakolat Waterfall: Kakolat Waterfall is one of the state’s prime tourist attractions, especially during the monsoon. Located near Nawada district, the waterfall and the pond at its base are surrounded by greenery, offering a serene atmosphere. Boating is a popular activity here.
Cycle around Bodhgaya: Bodhgaya is a UNESCO World Heritage site known for the Mahabodhi Temple, where Gautama Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment. Renting a cycle to explore the town and its surrounding areas provides a unique perspective on its history, architecture, and local life.
Trek to Mundeshwari Hills: The Mundeshwari Devi Temple, believed to be the oldest Hindu temple in India, sits atop the Mundeshwari Hills. Trekking up the hill not only offers a spiritual experience but also mesmerizing views of the surrounding landscape.
Sailing on the Ganges in Patna: The Ganges, one of the most revered rivers in India, flows through Patna, Bihar’s capital. You can rent a boat or join organized tours that offer sunset and sunrise sails. The experience of floating on this historic river, especially during sunrise or sunset, is ethereal.
Pilgrimage walks: Bihar has been significant in the life of Lord Buddha. Pilgrimage walks or ‘Parikramas’ around important Buddhist sites such as Rajgir, Nalanda, and Bodhgaya can be both spiritual and a way to enjoy the outdoors.
Visit the Kanwar Lake Bird Sanctuary: This is one of Asia’s largest freshwater oxbow lakes and a haven for bird watchers. The sanctuary hosts numerous migratory birds during winter months. It’s a paradise for photographers and nature lovers.
Picnic at Manjhar Kund: Also known as Manjhar K waterfall, it is one of the most beautiful waterfalls in Bihar, located near Sasaram. It’s a great spot for a picnic and to enjoy the natural surroundings.
Climbing the Griddhakuta Hill: Located in Rajgir, this is another significant site related to Buddhism. A climb up the hill is both an exercise and a pilgrimage, and the views from the top are rewarding.

Bihar, with its rich history intertwined with natural beauty, offers a plethora of options for outdoor enthusiasts. Whether you’re seeking adventure, serenity, or spiritual fulfillment, Bihar has something to offer. Remember to respect local customs and the environment, ensuring that these treasures are preserved for future generations.

Cedarville State Forest Pond
Situated in the heart of the Old Line State, Cedarville State Forest offers visitors a chance to reconnect with nature, find tranquility, and embark on exciting outdoor adventures. This 3,510-acre woodland reserve is the epitome of Maryland’s beautiful landscape.
Cedarville State Forest Campground is a reflection of Maryland’s natural beauty with dense woodlands, fragrant flora, and teeming wildlife. Tucked away from the hustle and bustle of city life, this sanctuary provides a serene backdrop for families, solo adventurers, and couples.

title: Cedarville State Forest Campground, MD, USA

Hiking : With over 19 miles of marked trails, Cedarville State Forest is a haven for hikers of all skill levels. The trails offer scenic views of native plants and wildlife.
Picnicking : There are designated areas with tables where you can enjoy a meal surrounded by nature.
Fishing : Bring your fishing pole and try your luck in the ponds stocked with bluegill, bass, and catfish.
Nature and Wildlife Watching : Be on the lookout for deer, turkey, fox, and a variety of bird species.
Horseback Riding : Certain trails are designated for equestrian use. Just remember to bring your own horse!

title: Hiking the Capital Crescent Trail: Urban Nature Retreat

Capital Crescent Trail


In the midst of the bustling urban life, I often seek solace and refuge in the serene embrace of nature during my hikes. Today, I’d like to share my recent adventure on the Capital Crescent Trail, a picturesque walking path that gracefully spans between two vibrant cities: Bethesda, Maryland, and Georgetown, Washington, D.C. This captivating trail extends over 7.0 miles, offering a point-to-point journey.
Our chosen route led us from Bethesda to Georgetown, presenting a delightful downhill course. The trail itself boasts a level terrain, cherished by runners, hikers, and cycling enthusiasts alike. While the initial 2.5 miles can be bustling on weekends, teeming with bikers and walkers, it gradually gives way to a quieter and more secluded path. Along the way, intermittent views of a winding river that flows parallel to the trail unfold.

What truly amazed us was the trail’s ability to maintain an oasis of tranquility amidst the urban surroundings, effectively drowning out the noise of city traffic. The three-hour trek to complete the trail left us exhausted but deeply fulfilled.
One of the trail’s distinct charms lies in the array of restaurants lining its trail heads. These proved to be a welcome sight for us, especially after a hearty meal at the first eatery we encountered.

Accessibility to the trail is a breeze, with convenient public transportation options. Personally, I opted for the metro, traveling to Bethesda and then making my way to the trailhead. On the return journey, I disembarked at Rosslyn station, situated merely a mile from the trail’s conclusion.
For those who wish to customize their hiking experience, the trail is ingeniously designed with multiple entry points, offering ample parking facilities. It’s an adventure that beckons a return visit—a prospect I eagerly anticipate in the rich tapestry of city life.

title: Navigating the Western Ridge and Valley Trail Loop of Rock Creek Park: A Hiker’s Perspective

Western Ridge and Valley Trail Loop of Rock Creek Park


Hiking, for me, offers a harmonious escape from the demands of daily life. One balmy morning in June, we set forth on the Western Ridge and Valley Trail Loop in the tranquil embrace of Rock Creek Park, Maryland. This scenic trail encompasses a 3.8-mile loop.

At times, it narrows and abounds with tree roots to navigate.



 


 



During our hike, we embarked on a side trail, which added an adventurous element. This path was narrow, winding, rocky, and covered with roots, making it somewhat precarious, especially given its proximity to a slope leading to the creek. A stumble or slip could be unsettling.
The hike featured several uphill sections and a few tricky spots in terms of footing in the latter half. We relied on our phones to stay on the trail, and even then, we had to adjust our course a few times. Along the way, we passed by a horse center, offering a unique opportunity to see horses on a city trail.
In sum, it was a pleasurable hike that commenced with a satisfying climb through the woods and offered enchanting river vistas in the second half. Remember to bring an ample supply of water, snacks, and bug spray to enhance your experience.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
text:
Photo by Caspian Dahlström on Unsplash
Survival should not be the first thing to come to mind while thinking about the great outdoors - it should be fun, adventure, mesmerizing views, a star-filled night, the sound of a waterfall, encountering wildlife, and making memories with your loved ones. However, as soon as you step outside the comforts and protection of your house, you are subjected to the elements and unforeseen difficult situations. Therefore, heading out with some basic preparedness is always helpful, especially with a family, including small children. This post is inspired by the famous 5Cs of survivability and the ten essentials by the National Park Services. And I hope these essential principles serve as your compass, guiding you through the rugged terrain and helping you emerge victorious in the face of nature’s trials.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Calmness: the anchor in the storm
text:
Calmness: the anchor in the storm
First, if you are met with an unpleasant event, such as getting lost on the hiking trail or injured, do not panic. I know it’s harder done than said, and freaking out in the face of a disaster is natural - especially when your kids are involved. However, maintaining a sense of calmness is your greatest asset. Panic clouds judgment and impedes decision-making. Instead, take a deep breath and embrace the stillness within. Calmness allows you to assess your situation, consider your options, and formulate a rational plan. A calm mind can save your life even in the face of danger.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: First aid kit: treat while you wait
text:
First aid kit: treat while you wait
A well-equipped first aid kit can be a lifesaver in any outdoor adventure. Accidents and injuries can happen unexpectedly, and being prepared with a first aid kit can make a significant difference in managing medical situations effectively. What a first aid kit should include depends on the nature of the activity and the people involved. Carrying a well-stocked first aid kit is a proactive step towards ensuring safety during outdoor expeditions. However, at a minimum, a good kit should include essential items like adhesive bandages, gauze pads, antiseptic wipes/creams, pain relievers, and any personal medications. Additionally, items such as a CAT tourniquet, splint materials, blister treatment, and compact emergency blankets are invaluable for addressing a variety of potential injuries.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Cutting: tools for crafting and survival
text:
Cutting: tools for crafting and survival
A cutting tool, such as fixed blade knives, multitools, axes, and saws (all fall under this category), can make a significant difference in your attempt at survival. These tools can be used for opening a first aid kit, crafting shelter, procuring food, and processing wood for fire, amongst numerous other things. I always keep a small Swiss Army Knife in my car that goes to my day back or waist pack when I hit the trail or a park with kids. If needed, I also carry a bigger multitool with a plier and a small saw that adds more functionality without adding much weight to my pack. Besides multitools, a fixed blade full tang knife is essential while camping overnight. If you are car camping, you can carry all three. However, a fixed-blade knife would be more reliable while backpacking camping, especially for processing firewood.
While car camping, I carry an 11-inch foldable saw, a multitool, and a fixed-blade knife. When writing this post, I have not gone backpacking camping, so I am still determining what I will take. But it most likely is my Morakniv full-tang fixed blade knife.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Combustion and light: harnessing the power of fire
text:
Combustion and light: harnessing the power of fire
Fire is a primal force that has been humanity’s ally for millennia. It provides warmth, light, a means to cook food, and a psychological boost in challenging times. In your survival kit, carry fire-starting tools like a box of matches (waterproof if possible), lighter, ferro rod, etc. Setting things up on fire is relatively easy. However, building a good fire for keeping warm for an extended period or cooking food can take some skills. Therefore, learning and practicing the fire building - from gathering tinder to kindler to fule and creating a sustainable blaze is helpful and fun. In the wilderness, fire is more than survival; it symbolizes resilience and adaptability.
On day hikes, I usually carry a small Bic lighter; they hardly weigh and always work. I carry waterproof matches, Bic lighters (small and big), a Ferro rod, and some fire-starting cubes for car camping. Fire-starting cubes are excellent while camping. They are effortless and can reduce the burden of finding the right tinder and kindling material. I like to use them, especially on a cold morning when I want to get the fire going quickly, mostly on its own, while cooking my breakfast.
A campfire can keep you warm and cook your food, but it’s not luminous or portable enough to let you navigate the campsite, set up a shelter, or go to the bathroom. Therefore, you need a dedicated battery-operated light source, which could be as simple as your phone’s camera flash or a cheap flashlight from the Dollar Store or Walmart. However, having a headlamp is most versatile in its utility.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Cover: sheltering yourself from the elements
text:
Cover: sheltering yourself from the elements
Proper clothing is your first line of defense against the harsh realities of the wilderness. Dressing appropriately for the environment is crucial to regulate body temperature and prevent hypothermia or heatstroke. Layering is critical, as it allows you to adjust to changing conditions. Sturdy, comfortable footwear is a must to navigate rugged terrain and prevent blisters. Remember, in the wild, your clothing is not just an outfit; it’s your shield against nature’s challenges.
Besides clothing, tarps (rain fly), ponchos (rain gear), and tents form the second line of defense against the elements. These cover options shield you from rain, wind, and sun, providing a safe haven to rest and regroup. Whether you are setting up a makeshift shelter or using a compact tent, having the means to create a protective barrier against the wild is essential.
Depending on the weather forecast, I carry a lightweight poncho on a day hike, which can also be spread on the ground to sit or lie down. If I am not carrying my multipurpose poncho, I carry a lightweight waterproof ground sheet/blanket for lying down. I do not carry tarps or tents on a day hike. However, while car camping with family, I carry several tarps for extra rain cover over our tent and cooking area and one emergency poncho for each family member.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
text:
Container: securing vital resources
A container – such as a water bottle – is handy for securing and transporting water. Water is paramount to survival, and having the means to collect and store it is non-negotiable. Containers can also be used to store edible plants, insects, or small game you might come across. Choose containers that are durable, leak-proof, and lightweight for easy portability.
For a short day hike, I usually carry two Smart (plastic) water bottles as they are lightweight, and I am not in danger of getting stranded for an extended period where I have to source water from my surroundings and purify it by boiling. However, if I am camping, I keep plastic water bottles/jugs as primary storage and a metal container, be it a water bottle (single-walled) or a kettle to boil the water. Of course, if you are backpacking, you will carry a kettle to boil the water for your ready-to-eat meals and coffee.
If you go to the beach, carry a double-walled insulated water bottle. It will add to the overall weight but keep your water cool even if you put it on the warm sand.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
text:
Cordage: your versatile lifeline
Any type of heavy-duty or multi-purpose string falls under the category of cordage. From setting up shelter to crafting tools and traps, cordage is the lifeline that enables you to secure, tie, and create. Whether paracord, natural fibers, or improvised materials, having a good supply of cordage opens up a world of possibilities in the wild.
I am a big fan of paracords from Dollar Tree (25 ft) and Temu.com (100 ft) for setting up tarps over my tent and cooking area. I use the 100 ft cord for the tarp’s ridgeline and 25 ft cords for the guylines, and so far, they have reached even the most distant spread of trees around my campsites.






Note



Paracords from Dollar Tree and Temu are cheap, but I would not trust them for critical load-bearing tasks. Even though they are sold as paracords, they do not have any load-bearing capacity rating. The rated 550 paracords should have a load-bearing capacity of 550 lbs.


Besides paracords, I also use tarred nylon twine #18 from Walmart’s fishing equipment section. They are also called banklines, and the famous one is #36. Bank lines are much cheaper than paracords and useful for crafts where you want to cut the cord and probably leave it in the wild. I use bank lines to make prusik knots to tension my tarp on the ridgeline.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Communications and navigation: your way to call for help and find your way around
text:
Communications and navigation: your way to call for help and find your way around
I cannot move around in the USA without GPS on my phone, and probably it’s the same for you unless you have lived in the region for a very long time. Also, phone is the only quick way to call for help. Therefore, it goes without saying to keep the phone charged all the time with an active and sufficient calling and data plan. I also tend to download offline maps of the region I will be traveling to in case there is poor internet connectivity, which usually is many National Parks.
Besides Google Maps, I also install alternative navigation software that does not depend on the internet, such as OsmAnd+ or Organic Maps. I also recommend paper maps and a compass. However, I realize that only a few people can navigate using a paper map and a compass. It’s a skill worth taking up, and several outdoorsy organizations teach it, including your local REI store.






Tip



Since our mobile phones are such an integral part of our lives, in addition to keeping my phone in a sturdy phone case, I also carry a waterproof case with floatation that I can hang around my neck with lanyards while I am on the water either kayaking or stand up paddle boarding. Just keeping your phone in a waterproof casing is enough for the rain, but it will sink if it is dropped in the water. Therefore, a case with flotation capabilities is a must.


While camping (with family), we also carry cheap walkie-talkie radios that kids can use while going to the bathroom or playing near the campsite. Unlike cell phones, radios within range do not need internet or communication towers to work.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
section: Sanitizers, bug spray, and sunscreens: keep the germs away and protect your skin
text:
Sanitizers, bug spray, and sunscreens: keep the germs away and protect your skin
People say there is nothing called hygiene and counting calories while outdoors. However, getting sick while camping or returning home is not fun. Therefore, keep a small bottle of hand sanitizer. They are not heavy, and some hygiene won’t hurt.
Bugs are everywhere. You are invading their home, so they will not like it and might want to hurt you. So, insect repellents are a must. They protect you from the discomfort of insect bites and insect-borne diseases. Please check the recommended dosage and type of insect repellent for kids before heading out.
For bears, while camping or going on long hikes like in the Shenandoah National Parks, I always carry a bear spray can with me. However, before carrying a bear spray, check the park rules if they are allowed and learn how to use them before they are needed in action. Other nonchemical methods to deter a black bear, like a pressure horn or a jingle bell attached to your pack, let the bear know there are people around.
Beaches are not the only place you might need a splash of sunscreen. Depending upon where you are hiking, you might encounter long stretches of unshaded regions where you may need sun protection. Therefore, keep a small tube of sunscreen.

title: Essentials for Outdoor Survival
text:
Final thoughts
Surviving in the outdoors demands respect for nature’s power and a deep understanding of your capabilities. In this article, I aimed to list the categories of tools and skills that will empower you to navigate challenges, make sound decisions, and harness the resources around you to ensure you are ready to take care of any unpleasant events for yourself and your family while enjoying the great outdoors. You can choose one tool per category or multiple, depending on the activity and the people involved. I try to be extra prepared with family and keep backup tools per category.
The purpose of this article was to prepare and make you think about what you might need in an outdoor survival situation. It is not to scare you or get paranoid about every little detail. For most outdoor activities, we are not far from help; therefore, don’t get too carried away thinking about survival and miss the beauty and enjoyment of the great outdoors. Otherwise, that would be self-defeating.
Now get on, and I might meet you on the trail!
